verses.text: At the end of every seven years you shall grant a release.
verses.comment: The command for a seven-year cycle of release parallels the Jubilee principle (Lev. 25:10), underscoring a rhythm of mercy and freedom established by God. Spiritually, it prefigures ultimate liberation in Christ (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: This is the manner of the release: every creditor shall release what he has lent to his neighbor. He shall not exact it from his neighbor or his brother, because the LORD's release has been proclaimed.
verses.comment: The release is rooted in divine authority—'the LORD's release'—emphasizing God's mercy as the basis for human forgiveness (see Matt. 18:21-35).

verses.text: You may require payment from a foreigner, but you shall release whatever is owed by your brother.
verses.comment: Israel is called to show special mercy within the covenant community. Spiritually, it implies deeper communal bonds set apart for God's people (Gal. 6:10).

verses.text: However, there should be no poor among you, for the LORD will greatly bless you in the land the LORD your God is giving you to possess as an inheritance—
verses.comment: God’s blessing aims to eradicate poverty among His people, a vision echoed in Acts 4:34. This points to a community of shared resources and charity, reflecting the unity Christ desires for His Church.

verses.text: If only you obey the LORD your God and are careful to follow all these commandments that I am commanding you today—
verses.comment: Obedience is key to experiencing God’s promised blessing. Fulfillment in Christ ties obedience to love (John 14:15), reinforcing communal fidelity.

verses.text: For the LORD your God will bless you, as He has promised you, and you will lend to many nations but will borrow from none. You will rule over many nations, but none will rule over you.
verses.comment: Prosperity and influence are linked to covenant faithfulness. The promise of not being subject to others recalls the spiritual freedom found in Christ (Rom. 6:14).

verses.text: If there is a poor man among your brothers within any of your towns in the land the LORD your God is giving you, do not harden your heart nor shut your hand against your poor brother.
verses.comment: Compassion for the poor is commanded, reflecting a heart like God's. Jesus expands this ethic in Matthew 25:40, affirming acts of mercy as service to Him.

verses.text: But you shall open your hand wide to him and lend him whatever he needs.
verses.comment: Giving generously goes beyond minimal obligation, anticipating the radical generosity taught by Christ. Spiritual unity is built through such charity.

verses.text: Be careful not to harbor this evil thought: ‘The seventh year, the year of release, is near,’ so you might look with hostility upon your poor brother and not give him anything; he may cry out to the LORD against you, and you will be guilty of sin.
verses.comment: Intentional avoidance of generosity is condemned. True charity flows from the transformation of the heart (see 1 John 3:17), a mark of true Christian fellowship.

verses.text: You shall surely give to him, and your heart shall not be grieved when you give to him, because for this thing the LORD your God will bless you in all your work and in all you undertake.
verses.comment: Generosity should be cheerful, as Paul reiterates in 2 Corinthians 9:7. Prosperity results from loving generosity, an echo of divine grace.

verses.text: For there will never cease to be poor in the land; therefore I command you to open your hand to your brother, to the needy and the poor in your land.
verses.comment: Acknowledging perpetual poverty calls for ongoing charity, as Jesus affirms in the Gospels, tying mercy to fellowship and spiritual blessing.

verses.text: If your brother, a Hebrew man or woman, is sold to you and serves you six years, then in the seventh year you shall set him free from your service.
verses.comment: Release from servitude upholds dignity and restoration to full community, prefiguring liberation through Christ (Rom. 8:2).

verses.text: And when you set him free, you shall not send him away empty-handed.
verses.comment: Liberation includes provision, expressing God’s generosity. This anticipates Christ’s teaching on caring for the marginalized (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: Supply him liberally from your flock, from your threshing floor, and from your winepress. Give to him as the LORD your God has blessed you.
verses.comment: Gracious giving reflects God’s own blessing. It encourages practical and spiritual generosity—an outward sign of inner transformation.

verses.text: Remember that you were slaves in the land of Egypt and the LORD your God redeemed you; that is why I command you this today.
verses.comment: Redemption from Egypt sets the pattern for redemption through Christ (Col. 1:13–14). Memory of deliverance inspires ongoing mercy.

verses.text: But if your servant says to you, ‘I do not want to leave you,’ because he loves you and your household, since he is well off with you—
verses.comment: Permanent servitude becomes voluntary and born out of love—a type for loyal discipleship and devoted service within Christ’s Body.

verses.text: Then you shall take an awl and drive it through his ear into the door, and he will be your servant forever. Also to your female servant you shall do likewise.
verses.comment: This ritual signifies lifetime dedication. Spiritually, it echoes Christian self-surrender—marked by the sign or seal of belonging (cf. Gal. 6:17).

verses.text: It shall not seem hard to you when you set him free, for he has served you six years worth twice the wages of a hired worker; the LORD your God will bless you in all that you do.
verses.comment: The release after faithful service is not a loss but a blessing. God's blessing follows acts of justice and generosity.

verses.text: All the firstborn males that are born of your herds and flocks you shall dedicate to the LORD your God. You shall not work with the firstborn of your cattle nor shear the firstborn of your sheep.
verses.comment: Consecration of firstborn animals reflects the principle of giving God the first and best—an act of worship symbolizing the dedication of one’s life (Rom. 12:1).

verses.text: You shall eat it, you and your household, before the LORD your God year by year at the place the LORD will choose.
verses.comment: Communal worship and fellowship through sacred meals foreshadow spiritual unity, pointing towards the practice of eating together in sacred celebration (Acts 2:46).

verses.text: But if it has any defect—if it is lame or blind or has any serious defect—you shall not sacrifice it to the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Only perfect offerings are acceptable, foreshadowing Christ’s sinless sacrifice—He offered Himself without blemish (Heb. 9:14).

verses.text: You shall eat it within your gates; the unclean and the clean may eat it, as they eat the gazelle or the deer.
verses.comment: Common participation, regardless of ritual status, hints at the later inclusion of all believers in fellowship—a principle expanded by Christ.

verses.text: But you shall not eat its blood; you shall pour it out on the ground like water.
verses.comment: The prohibition of blood signifies respect for life, anticipating Christ’s blood poured out for many—a sign of the New Covenant (Matt. 26:28).
